Award.AwardTitle: Structural Role of Flightin in Thick Filaments of Drosophila Flight Muscle

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Movement is one of the fundamental properties of living organisms. In most animals, movement is powered by contraction of striated muscles, so called because of their highly regular and repetitive organization of protein filaments that are seen as striations under a microscope. All striated muscles contain thick filaments whose main component is myosin, the evolutionarily conserved motor protein responsible for generating the force for muscle contraction. Thick filaments from different muscle types have distinct structural and mechanical properties that are imparted by non-myosin thick filament proteins. Thus, these proteins play a significant role in defining functional differences among muscle types. This research will address the functions of flightin, a novel thick filament protein that is essential for the structural integrity and mechanical stability of the flight muscle in the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster. Specifically, this project aims to elucidate the molecular interaction between flightin and myosin through a combination of in vitro biochemical studies and in vivo genetic approaches. A key hypothesis of this work is that a conserved amino acid region in flightin (of approximately 52 amino acids) identifies a new myosin binding domain that is widespread among two major groups of invertebrates, the insects and the crustaceans. To elucidate the structural basis of flightin function, a detailed three dimensional model of the thick filament from the fruit fly flight muscle will be generated by tomography from images obtained with an electron microscope. A combination of molecular labeling techniques and comparison of filament structures with and without flightin will result in the identification and localization of flightin in the thick filament. These studies will provide the first higher resolution three-dimensional structure of thick filaments from a model genetic organism and will provide the foundation for the structural analysis of a plethora of Drosophila melanogaster flight muscle mutants with known genetic, biochemical, and mechanical defects. Additionally, the impact of this research will extend to areas of evolutionary biology and phylogenetics that seek to understand the diversification of life forms as exemplified by the insects, arguably the most successful group of animals.

Broader impacts
This research will have impacts in the areas of education and the generation of biological reagents for the Drosophila and muscle research communities. Previous NSF funding to this research group has been instrumental in training undergraduate and graduate students, including members from underrepresented groups and disadvantaged backgrounds, and this project is designed to integrate research with continuing educational opportunities. Knowledge generated from this research will find its way to advanced undergraduate and graduate specialty courses, review articles and book chapters intended for the research community, and articles and stories for the non-scientific audience. Results will be broadly disseminated through our website, publications in peer-reviewed journals, and by undergraduate and graduate students who will present their work at scientific meetings. All reagents (DNA clones, mutant and transgenic strains) will be freely available to other investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Muscle generates force through the interaction of myosin, a motor protein, with actin. In striated muscle (such as human skeletal and cardiac muscle), myosin and myosin-binding proteins form biopolymers known as thick filaments. The goal of this research was to understand the functional properties of flightin, a myosin-binding protein, and its contribution to the structure and function of thick filaments and of muscle. To achieve this goal, we created transgenic fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) expressing mutant versions of flightin and expressing a non-fly myosin binding protein, human cardiac myosin binding protein-C (cMyBP-C). These studies revealed that flightin is involved in determining the length and the stiffness of thick filaments and that cMyBP-C fulfills similar roles. Specifically, we found that different sections (i.e., protein domains) of flightin fulfill two important roles: an amino-terminal domain is primarily responsible for stiffening the thick filament, while a carboxy-terminal domain is primarily responsible for length determination. We identified a third protein domain, named WYR, that resides between the amino-terminal domain and the carboxy-terminal domain.  We found WYR is a novel protein domain that is evolutionarily conserved in over 80 species of hexapods (insects and the like) and crustaceans, two groups that together constitute the majority of animal species. We traced the origin of flightin to ~500 million years ago, around the time insects and crustaceans shared a common ancestor. Additionally, we investigated the role of the flight muscle in the generation of the courtship song in Drosophila and determined that the N-terminal domain of flightin contributes to the definition of song attributes that female flies use to identify males of their species and to discriminate between potential mates. As such, this project was the first to examine how muscle proteins have evolved to fulfill two critical roles of the flight muscle in enabling powered flight and courtship song production. Another important outcome of this project was the creation of a new experimental platform to quantify walking and flight behavior in large cohorts of flies. Currently under beta testing, this custom-built platform and associated image acquisition software will have many potential uses for the study of muscle function and fly behavior.

The project contributed to education and provided significant research training opportunities to nearly fifty individuals, including pre-college, college, and graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and research faculty. All project participants presented their results at regional, national and international conferences, or in peer-reviewed publications. The project inspired the creation of three courses (one graduate and two undergraduate) at the University of Vermont.
